Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A crane is holding a heavy beam in position, and you must immediately help guide it into place before it can be secured.
Story: I was still in my work boots, dust clinging to my clothes, when my phone buzzed. It was Mom, her voice trembling as she told me about Dad’s health scare. She needed me to listen, to reassure her, to be the grown-up child she could lean on. My heart twisted—I wanted to be there, to say the right words, to hold her hand through the phone. But just then, the foreman shouted my name. The crane was swinging a steel beam overhead, and I was needed on the ground, hands steady, eyes sharp, guiding the load before it could be bolted in place. My coworkers depended on me; a single mistake could mean disaster. I could hear Mom’s quiet sobs, but the clang of metal and the urgency in my boss’s voice pulled me in the opposite direction. I stood frozen, the phone pressed to my ear, the weight of two worlds demanding all of me at once.
